title: Black Cat Bicycles Mystery Spot Full Suspension – Todd Ingermanson & John Watson
content:
Todd from Black Cat doesn’t use CAD or any computer-assisted tools in his small workshop outside of Santa Cruz, California. Everything is hand-drafted at 1:1 scale, and solutions for complex problems often require prototypes and extensive problem-solving. That includes bikes like John’s Swami Bi-Lam Rigid 29er, all the way up to complex DW Link bikes like this Mystery Spot MX full suspension.

While John was in the Bay Area earlier this spring, he met up with Todd late one afternoon to document this bike. Read on for words from Todd on what makes these projects so special alongside some tasty photos from John…

Mystery Spot Quick Hits

  • 120 mm rear/140 mm front travel
  • 27.5″ rear 29″ front MX mullet wheelset- shorter chainstay allows for a more playful ride
  • DW Link suspension platform
  • Long upper link: allows long stroke shock, more tunability, less overheating, etc
  • Short lower link: less rearward axle path, less small bump absorption, but more “pop” to the ride
  • There are a lot of semi-boring numbers semi-associated with how the bike rides and fits
  • Currently for sale
  • One-off, ground-up project

A couple of years ago, I built myself the Hocus Pocus because I wanted a “full” to ride. I’d worked in the mainstream bike industry previously, but it seemed right to build it myself, rather than lean on a friend for a carbon wonder bike. The bike got some attention, and an overseas customer reached out for something similar. He wanted a 27.5″ rear wheel and a tight rear center to maintain a lively ride, and also wanted the trussed swingarm from the previous bike. I’d made the original bike swingarm a truss to solve an interference problem, but for this bike, it’s much more of an aesthetic choice, and paired with the trussed upper link, is an undeniable visual focal point.

The customer wanted a bike that was more playful than recent suspension platforms, which more and more completely isolated the rider from the terrain. While that might be faster in a race setting, it doesn’t lend itself to using the natural undulations as features to play with. Once we came up with a good idea of what he wanted and I could provide, I talked at great length with Evan Turpen of Contra Bikes, a friend and neighbor with legit full-sus bona fides, who’d helped me out with the kinematics on the Hocus Pocus. He had some ideas kicking around in his head – he always does! – so we came up with some expectations and compromises, and he came up with all the kinematics for the design.

The name “Mystery Spot” is from Santa Cruz’s very own world-famous old-timey roadside attraction, and is a play on all the moving (virtual) pivot location buzzwords. And… credit to where credit is due, it was coined by Steven at SimWorks. He’s obviously some kind of marketing genius with gems like that.

This bike was built almost entirely as a backup for the commissioned bike, as any late-stage mistake could have rendered the previous months’ effort a total waste. Fortunately, I somehow managed to hold it all together, and both bikes came out as intended.

No one was more surprised than I! HA! While I really enjoy digging into the details of all the bikes I build, sometimes it’s pretty fun/challenging/maddening/rewarding to stand back and start a project, truly from ground zero. Definitely no phoning it in.

Every bike (and everything in life, it seems) is a spec list that doubles as a list of compromises. To get one thing, you give up another. No Free Lunches(!), and this bike is no different. Being made of a lot of steel tubes, it certainly is not as light as a carbon wonder bike, but that’s ok. The metrics used to judge things are different for different people. No matter what random numbers it’s judged by, there certainly won’t be two of these at the trailhead.

This is not by any means a production bike, and one-off bikes lack the economy of scale that allows modern engineering marvels to be affordable. As such, it’s not.

This bike is up for grabs, and I’m always interested in future ground-up projects, so drop a line if you are too.

 

 

Many thanks to Todd for sharing his thoughts on the Mystery Spot MX Full Suspension. Check out more at Black Cat Bicycles.
